cons: As an old organization, sometimes takes time to adjust to the new times quickly.

pros: Lovely place to work. Good colleagues.

review_title: Using business and technical skills to help advance the Gospel!

pros: Got to climb towers and drive backhoe and do desk work.
cons: Raising family in Guam has challenges.

pros:
An organization that cut its teeth on radio is working hard to adjust to the changing times without sacrificing the faithful relationships of the people who got them where they are today.

How they work is more important than what they produce.  They want to honor the Lord as their first priority, and see the Bible as the ultimate authority divinely inspired by God Himself.
cons: Growing pains - how do you take a tech/media organization that started in the 50's and make it work in the 2050's?  Flexibility, experimentation, trial & error - sometimes the errors hurt.

job_title: Social Media Coordinator in Cary, NC
pros: I really couldn’t have known the family I was joining when I started working for TWR. The people are wonderful to work with, very kingdom-minded, encouraging, and excel in their fields. I always feel heard and appreciated, even and especially when the job gets busy. It’s more than just a job — I have such purpose in my work, and it’s incredible to see how the Lord can use every skill set in the book to help further the gospel. It doesn’t matter if you have gifts in finance, engineering, administration, management, graphic design, radio, or marketing — literally every skill set can find a home here.
cons: I truly have no complaints.

pros:
I worked at TWR for two years full-time out of the Cary, NC office, and then one year part-time (remotely) in the Raleigh area, once I had our son. 

TWR has a very unique, special culture that is hard to explain unless you've experienced it. "Trust" is a fundamental aspect of their culture. I always felt like I was given the benefit of the doubt. I was able to work remotely, as-needed, shortly after being hired. 

Because I worked in HR, I was involved in a number of meetings where I saw some of the behind-the-scenes planning on hiring, staff retention, and meeting corporate needs. I feel that, although I wasn't in a leadership role, I gained a different perspective than someone in another department may have because I heard the hearts of fellow co-workers behind closed doors. I would emphasize how "people-focused" TWR is; their main concern is the health of their staff--spiritually and in all other aspects.  

They have a dynamic mission and vision: a true heart to reach the nations with the gospel. All of the co-workers that I knew well, were the "real deal" with their sincerity. 

After we had our son, 12 co-workers came to our home to visit us and/or bring dinner the weeks following. I was provided with several weeks paid maternity leave. The company sent us flowers to our home with a card signed by the staff. When I requested to go part-time, mostly remotely, I felt that my department had a "How can we keep you?" attitude, as oppose to "You need to bend to fit what we want." I never felt that I was being forced to choose the ministry or my family. I felt that TWR supported my family's needs 100%. 

There are a lot of really cool aspects of TWR related to content that they produce, the projects you could be involved in, and the ability to reach people on the other side of the world with the gospel, but the biggest "selling point" to me is how the leadership and staff treat you. I always felt valued, heard, and cared about.
cons:
The two biggest issues for TWR: pay and upward mobility. 

HR does a great job trying to retain their members with extremely flexible work schedules, the ability to work remotely, and perks like "discount benefits" on gym memberships. The reality is, pay is always going to be a struggle when you work for a ministry/non-profit. It is also a challenge if you live in the Triangle, because the cost of housing can be expensive to support a family. I know this is something that the HR team is continually trying to work on -- to create incentives for their staff -- but the truth is, you have to be drawn to TWR for a reason much deeper than pay. You have to fall in-love with the mission and vision and want to serve, otherwise you won't stay.  

The lack of upward mobility has more to do with how the company is structured. There isn't a lot of middle management positions. I was at more of an entry-level position, and felt that there wasn't any "open" positions between me and the director of my department. Positions could be created, but may be limited by timing and funding. This problem is the ministry's achilles heel for retaining anyone under 35.  I know that the HR Department is actively working on this problem, but it will likely be a slower change.

pros: TWR is a truly family-style atmosphere. People believe in helping each other out whenever possible and most of the staff is quite friendly. The organization allows people to use either a Mac or PC for work, which is nice.
cons: Many of the staff have been part of the organization for 10+ years. While this shows stability, there is not much room for upward mobility in the company.

pros: The staff with TWR are incredibly caring. They truly will bend over backward to help someone. Overall, the benefits are great and the management is very flexible with employees. Some departments are very growth oriented and lend to great opportunity for overall development.
cons: Compensation is not incredibly competitive, but TWR is a non-profit, so I don't expect to make much. Much of the young talent seems to be leaving for various reasons.

pros: Every day I get to use my skills to be a part of bringing the message of God's love to millions of people across the world.
cons: As a nonprofit, the salaries are enough to live on, but not quite as much as the local high tech industries.

pros:
Friendly and open and, at the same time, professional office culture.
Great opportunities to work in an international and cross-cultural setting.
cons:
Lack of inspirational leadership with clear sense of direction for the future.
Limited opportunities for professional growth.

review_title: Great ministry that's transforming our world
